awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Diet and defense: characterizing the relationship between poison frogs and their tropical ant prey
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Broadening Participation of Groups Underrepresented in Biology. The Fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The research project will focus on the relationship between tropical poison frogs and their toxic ant prey through both field-based and lab-based experiments. Poison frogs feed on toxic insects to obtain their chemical defense, consuming only a small subset of ants when compared to all those available, but little is known about how and why these specific choices are made. As tropical habitats disappear due to human modification and the changing environment, insects will continue to decline. The project will test poison frogs prey choice to determine the specificity of their diet, and the severity of the extinction threat they may face if their ant prey disappears due to the current global insect loss. The Fellow will also focus on broadening the participation of historically underrepresented groups in Biology by collaborating with local schools to provide tools to conduct frog research, as well as mentoring, collaborating with, and supporting undergraduate students and postdoctoral researchers at the host institution. 

To understand the specificity of poison frog prey selection and possible behavioral drivers, the Fellow will combine field sampling in South America and laboratory experiments at the host institution and will ask if prey toxicity or morphology drives frog prey selection. Chemical profiles from wild-caught poison frogs and ant prey will be characterized using gas chromatography and mass spectrometry, and frog stomach contents will be dissected and identified using DNA barcoding. Community ants will be collected to compare diet selection to overall ant availability, and morphology of ants will be quantified using size and coloration measurements. Frog colonies at the host institution will be employed to test behavioral drivers of prey selection, including size and toxicity, and measuring foraging response. The Fellow will participate in broadening the representation of historically underrepresented students in Biology by 1) partnering with local students to bring independent frog research into the K-12 classroom, 2) mentoring and providing academic resources to undergraduate students with intersectional identities, and 3) recruiting and collaborating with postdoctoral scholars at the host institution. The Fellow will also pursue training in current pedagogical techniques with a focus on inclusive teaching methods and developing course materials at the host institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to further characterize the relationship between diet-derived defense and prey selection in Dendrobatid poison frogs. The field has lacked careful experimentation to answer questions related to prey specificity of poison frogs in the wild. Through this funding, I have developed a method to use previously stored samples in ethanol for nutritional analyses, in addition to other morphological and chemical measurements of poison frog prey. This will reduce the number of animals analyzed in the field, in addition to increasing our understanding of Dendrobatid diet selection, which may include insect species previously unidentified. This method has been optimized in lab animals, and will be submitted for publication to directly impact field sampling methods in the future. Studying a charismatic species, like poison frogs, lends well to both public outreach and interventions along the academic pipeline to increase interest and retention in STEM by historically excluded groups. This project has allowed me to partner with the LPS program, which hopes to inspire a passion for STEM and build a relationship between STEM mentors and middle school students from backgrounds historically excluded from science. Additionally, I was invited to bring exciting research seminars to primarily undergraduate institutions that serve the public of California, where I discussed academic pipelines and my own research journey with undergraduate students. I have also partnered with a local high school teacher to take research experiences and adapt them into future curriculum for students. Using research related to poison frogs and ants, we developed teaching materials that I used in the local community college classroom as a guest lecturer. I hope to continue to leverage this study system to increase public awareness and excitement about arthropods and poison frogs, and to bring an adaptable research program and classroom experience to the Bay Area community and beyond.

This project has also allowed me to complete the postdoc teaching certificate at Stanford, a program focused on increasing skills related to evidence-based pedagogical practices in undergraduate STEM education through 80 hours of training. In addition, I have co-taught two research courses, where I developed a protocol for students to use homemade aspirators to collect local ants and extract their chemical profiles, bringing this project to a larger audience and transferring skills to the future STEM academics and industry workforce. Both results of these courses have been published by undergraduate students in a peer-reviewed journal. Additionally, I became a Preparing Future Professors Fellow at Stanford and worked with a local community college professor over a ten week term to shadow and gain skills in a new academic setting. I have had numerous outreach opportunities to pursue the broader impacts of this project including at the middle school, high school, community college, and state university level. I have connected with students, professors, and members of the public to spur an interest in poison frogs and their relationship to ants, and biology more broadly. I have had the opportunity to re-write pre-conceived notions about entomology as a field and what a scientist looks like, and have hoped to instill the importance of community stewardship of the environment outside of poison frogs and ants. 


Last Modified: 05/31/2024
Modified by: Katherine Fiocca
